required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: CPR Quality and Use of Feedback for OHCA
clinical_study.official_title: Cardio-Pulmonary-Resuscitation Quality in Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest - Effect of Real-time Feedback and Post-event Debriefing

lead_sponsor.agency: Emergency Medical Services, Capital Region, Denmark

clinical_study.source: Emergency Medical Services, Capital Region, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the quality of cardio-pulmonary resuscitation(CPR) delivered by EMS professionals and whether this quality can be improved by implementing real-time feedback during the event and an oral post-event debriefing procedure based on the actual event performance data.

detailed_description.textblock:
The aim of this study is to investigate whether CPR quality can be improved by implementing real-time feedback and immediate oral structured post-event debriefing in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA).
The objectives of this study is to assess the current quality of CPR delivered by emergency medical services (EMS) during OHCA events in the Capital Region of Denmark. Furthermore, to investigate if CPR quality can be improved by applying real-time feedback during OHCA resuscitation attempts and to investigate if structured oral post-event debriefing delivered immediately after a resuscitation attempt and based on data from the defibrillator can further improve CPR quality
The hypothesis of this study is that adding real-time and post event feedback can improve the compression rate, compression depth, overall CPR hands-on time (CPR fraction), and recoil with at least 15% in total for both interventions.
Using a prospective study design data is retrieved from the standard defibrillator (ZOLL X series) through ZOLL RescueNetÂ® Case Review (software for post-event review, analysis, and debriefing) from ZOLL Medical Corporation, Massachusetts, United States of America.
The study consists of three consecutive phases. Phase one with no feedback / debriefing available for EMS. Phase two with real-time feedback during the event and phase three which adds post-event debriefing to real-time feedback. We expect to be able to include at least 500 cases in each phase.

primary_outcome.time_frame: During cardiopulmonary resuscitation performed by emergency medical services, up to 4 hours
primary_outcome.description: Chest compression depth is defined as the maximum posterior deflection of the sternum prior to chest recoil. Measured in centimeters

primary_outcome.time_frame: During cardiopulmonary resuscitation performed by emergency medical services, up to 4 hours
primary_outcome.description: Chest compression rate is defined as the frequency of chest compressions during compression series. Measured in number per minute.

primary_outcome.time_frame: During cardiopulmonary resuscitation performed by emergency medical services, up to 4 hours
primary_outcome.description: Chest compression fraction is defined as the time with chest compressions starting from the first therapeutic event to the end of the episode. An episode is the time without presence of a spontaneous patient pulse. Measured in percentage.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During cardiopulmonary resuscitation performed by emergency medical services, up to 4 hours
secondary_outcome.description: The return of a spontaneous pulse prior to handover at hospital

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From the time of CPR attempt termination or handover at hospital to a new assignment is handed to the crew, up to 1 hour
secondary_outcome.description: The total number of time the individual EMS professional has been exposed to the post-event debriefing procedure

arm_group.description: Real-time feedback on chest compression depth, chest compression rate and recoil available to EMS while performing CPR. Feedback is delivered as visual text, numeric and graphical presentations on the defibrillator with audio tones for rate.

Structured oral post-event debriefing based on objective performance data from the resuscitation attempt. The debriefing is conducted as hot/immediate self-directed debriefing session with a maximum length of 10 minutes.

intervention.description: Real-time feedback on chest compression depth, chest compression rate and recoil available to EMS while performing CPR. Feedback is delivered as visual text, numeric and graphical presentations on the defibrillator with audio tones for rate.

Structured oral post-event debriefing based on objective performance data from the resuscitation attempt. The debriefing is conducted as hot/immediate self-directed debriefing session with a maximum length of 10 minutes.

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients in OHCA in the Capital Region of Denmark who receive CPR for at least 2 minutes delivered by or under supervision of EMS professionals with the standard defibrillator attached.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
OHCA
Exclusion Criteria:
No use of EMS defibrillator attached to patient during resuscitation attempt Less than 2 minutes of CPR with EMS defibrillator attached to patient OHCA with non-adult algorithm (Age 17 or younger) OHCA without involvement of the physician manned vehicle Patients who are subject to mechanical CPR from the time of device attachment Traumatic OHCA

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Emergency Medical Services, Capital Region, Denmark

patient_data.ipd_description: Danish legislation do not allow for sharing of individual patient data without patient consent
